column2: Grandmother told him she was sure the Lord had remembered these things to his credit, and had helped him out of many a scrape when he did n't realize that he was being protected by Providence.
column3: Grandmother told him she was sure the Lord had remembered these things to his credit, and had helped him out of many a scrape when he did n't realize that he was being protected by Providence.

column2: FOR several weeks after my sleigh-ride, we heard nothing from the Shimerdas.
column3: FOR several weeks after my sleigh ride, we heard nothing from the Shimerdas.

column2: My sore throat kept me indoors, and grandmother had a cold which made the housework heavy for her.
column3: My sore throat kept me indoors, and grandmother had a cold which made the housework heavy for her.

column2: When Sunday came she was glad to have a day of rest.
column3: When Sunday came she was glad to have a day of rest.

column2: One night at supper Fuchs told us he had seen Mr. Shimerda out hunting.
column3: One night at supper Fuchs told us he had seen mr Shimerda out hunting.

column2: He's made himself a rabbit-skin cap, Jim, and a rabbit-skin collar that he buttons on outside his coat.	He's made himself a rabbit skin cap, Jim, and a rabbit skin collar that he buttons on outside his coat.
column3: true

column2: They ain't got but one overcoat among 'em over there, and they take turns wearing it.
column3: They ain't got but one overcoat among 'em over there, and they take turns wearing it.

column2: They seem awful scared of cold, and stick in that hole in the bank like badgers."
column3: They seem awful scared of cold, and stick in that hole in the bank like badgers."

column2: All but the crazy boy, Jake put in.
column3: All but the crazy boy, Jake put in.

column2: He never wears the coat.	He never wears the coat.

column2: Krajiek says he's turrible strong and can stand anything.
column3: Krajiek says he's turrible strong and can stand anything.

column2: I guess rabbits must be getting scarce in this locality.
column3: I guess rabbits must be getting scarce in this locality.

column2: Ambrosch come along by the cornfield yesterday where I was at work and showed me three prairie dogs he'd shot. He asked me if they was good to eat.
column3: Ambrosch come along by the cornfield yesterday where I was at work and showed me three prairie dogs he'd shot. He asked me if they was good to eat.

column2: I spit and made a face and took on, to scare him, but he just looked like he was smarter'n me and put 'em back in his sack and walked off."
column3: I spit and made a face and took on, to scare him, but he just looked like he was smarter'n me and put 'em back in his sack and walked off."

column2: Grandmother looked up in alarm and spoke to grandfather.
column3: Grandmother looked up in alarm and spoke to grandfather.

column2: Josiah, you don't suppose Krajiek would let them poor creatures eat prairie dogs, do you?
column3: Josiah, you don't suppose Krajiek would let them poor creatures eat prairie dogs, do you?

column2: You had better go over and see our neighbors to-morrow, Emmaline, he replied gravely.
column3: You had better go over and see our neighbors to morrow, Emmaline, he replied gravely.

column2: Fuchs put in a cheerful word and said prairie dogs were clean beasts and ought to be good for food, but their family connections were against them. I asked what he meant, and he grinned and said they belonged to the rat family.
column3: Fuchs put in a cheerful word and said prairie dogs were clean beasts and ought to be good for food, but their family connections were against them. I asked what he meant, and he grinned and said they belonged to the rat family.

column2: When I went downstairs in the morning, I found grandmother and Jake packing a hamper basket in the kitchen.
column3: When I went downstairs in the morning, I found grandmother and Jake packing a hamper basket in the kitchen.

column2: Now, Jake, grandmother was saying, "if you can find that old rooster that got his comb froze, just give his neck a twist, and we'll take him along.
column3: Now, Jake, grandmother was saying, "if you can find that old rooster that got his comb froze, just give his neck a twist, and we'll take him along.

column2: There's no good reason why Mrs. Shimerda could n't have got hens from her neighbors last fall and had a henhouse going by now.
column3: There's no good reason why mrs Shimerda could n't have got hens from her neighbors last fall and had a henhouse going by now.

column2: I reckon she was confused and did n't know where to begin.
column3: I reckon she was confused and did n't know where to begin.

column2: I've come strange to a new country myself, but I never forgot hens are a good thing to have, no matter what you don't have."
column3: I've come strange to a new country myself, but I never forgot hens are a good thing to have, no matter what you don't have."

column2: Just as you say, mam, said Jake, "but I hate to think of Krajiek getting a leg of that old rooster." He tramped out through the long cellar and dropped the heavy door behind him.
column3: Just as you say, mam, said Jake, "but I hate to think of Krajiek getting a leg of that old rooster." He tramped out through the long cellar and dropped the heavy door behind him.

column2: After breakfast grandmother and Jake and I bundled ourselves up and climbed into the cold front wagon-seat.
column3: After breakfast grandmother and Jake and I bundled ourselves up and climbed into the cold front wagon seat.

column2: As we approached the Shimerdas' we heard the frosty whine of the pump and saw Antonia, her head tied up and her cotton dress blown about her, throwing all her weight on the pump-handle as it went up and down.
column3: As we approached the Shimerdas' we heard the frosty whine of the pump and saw Antonia, her head tied up and her cotton dress blown about her, throwing all her weight on the pump handle as it went up and down.

column2: She heard our wagon, looked back over her shoulder, and catching up her pail of water, started at a run for the hole in the bank.
column3: She heard our wagon, looked back over her shoulder, and catching up her pail of water, started at a run for the hole in the bank.

column2: Jake helped grandmother to the ground, saying he would bring the provisions after he had blanketed his horses.
column3: Jake helped grandmother to the ground, saying he would bring the provisions after he had blanketed his horses.

column2: We went slowly up the icy path toward the door sunk in the drawside.
column3: We went slowly up the icy path toward the door sunk in the drawside.

column2: Blue puffs of smoke came from the stovepipe that stuck out through the grass and snow, but the wind whisked them roughly away.
column3: Blue puffs of smoke came from the stovepipe that stuck out through the grass and snow, but the wind whisked them roughly away.

column2: Mrs. Shimerda opened the door before we knocked and seized grandmother's hand.
column3: mrs Shimerda opened the door before we knocked and seized grandmother's hand.

column2: She did not say "How do!" as usual, but at once began to cry, talking very fast in her own language, pointing to her feet which were tied up in rags, and looking about accusingly at every one.
column3: She did not say "How do!" as usual, but at once began to cry, talking very fast in her own language, pointing to her feet which were tied up in rags, and looking about accusingly at every one.

column2: The old man was sitting on a stump behind the stove, crouching over as if he were trying to hide from us.
column3: The old man was sitting on a stump behind the stove, crouching over as if he were trying to hide from us.

column2: Yulka was on the floor at his feet, her kitten in her lap.
column3: Yulka was on the floor at his feet, her kitten in her lap.

column2: She peeped out at me and smiled, but, glancing up at her mother, hid again.
column3: She peeped out at me and smiled, but, glancing up at her mother, hid again.

column2: Antonia was washing pans and dishes in a dark corner.
column3: Antonia was washing pans and dishes in a dark corner.

column2: The crazy boy lay under the only window, stretched on a gunnysack stuffed with straw.
column3: The crazy boy lay under the only window, stretched on a gunnysack stuffed with straw.

column2: As soon as we entered he threw a grainsack over the crack at the bottom of the door.
column3: As soon as we entered he threw a grainsack over the crack at the bottom of the door.

column2: The air in the cave was stifling, and it was very dark, too.
column3: The air in the cave was stifling, and it was very dark, too.

column2: A lighted lantern, hung over the stove, threw out a feeble yellow glimmer.
column3: A lighted lantern, hung over the stove, threw out a feeble yellow glimmer.

column2: Mrs. Shimerda snatched off the covers of two barrels behind the door, and made us look into them.
column3: mrs Shimerda snatched off the covers of two barrels behind the door, and made us look into them.

column2: In one there were some potatoes that had been frozen and were rotting, in the other was a little pile of flour. Grandmother murmured something in embarrassment, but the Bohemian woman laughed scornfully, a kind of whinny-laugh, and catching up an empty coffee-pot from the shelf, shook it at us with a look positively vindictive.
column3: In one there were some potatoes that had been frozen and were rotting, in the other was a little pile of flour. Grandmother murmured something in embarrassment, but the Bohemian woman laughed scornfully, a kind of whinny laugh, and catching up an empty coffee pot from the shelf, shook it at us with a look positively vindictive.

column2: Grandmother went on talking in her polite Virginia way, not admitting their stark need or her own remissness, until Jake arrived with the hamper, as if in direct answer to Mrs. Shimerda's reproaches.
column3: Grandmother went on talking in her polite Virginia way, not admitting their stark need or her own remissness, until Jake arrived with the hamper, as if in direct answer to mrs Shimerda's reproaches.

column2: Then the poor woman broke down.
column3: Then the poor woman broke down.

column2: She dropped on the floor beside her crazy son, hid her face on her knees, and sat crying bitterly.
column3: She dropped on the floor beside her crazy son, hid her face on her knees, and sat crying bitterly.

column2: Grandmother paid no heed to her, but called Antonia to come and help empty the basket.
column3: Grandmother paid no heed to her, but called Antonia to come and help empty the basket.

column2: Tony left her corner reluctantly.
column3: Tony left her corner reluctantly.

column2: I had never seen her crushed like this before.
column3: I had never seen her crushed like this before.

column2: You not mind my poor mamenka, Mrs. Burden.	You not mind my poor mamenka, mrs Burden.
column3: true

column2: She is so sad," she whispered, as she wiped her wet hands on her skirt and took the things grandmother handed her.
column3: She is so sad," she whispered, as she wiped her wet hands on her skirt and took the things grandmother handed her.

column2: The crazy boy, seeing the food, began to make soft, gurgling noises and stroked his stomach.
column3: The crazy boy, seeing the food, began to make soft, gurgling noises and stroked his stomach.

column2: Jake came in again, this time with a sack of potatoes.
column3: Jake came in again, this time with a sack of potatoes.

column2: Grandmother looked about in perplexity.
column3: Grandmother looked about in perplexity.

column2: Have n't you got any sort of cave or cellar outside, Antonia?	Have n't you got any sort of cave or cellar outside, Antonia?
column3: true

column2: This is no place to keep vegetables.
column3: This is no place to keep vegetables.

column2: How did your potatoes get frozen?"
column3: How did your potatoes get frozen?"

column2: We get from Mr. Bushy, at the post-office,--what he throw out.	We get from mr Bushy, at the post office,--what he throw out.
column3: true

column2: We got no potatoes, Mrs. Burden," Tony admitted mournfully.
column3: We got no potatoes, mrs Burden," Tony admitted mournfully.

column2: When Jake went out, Marek crawled along the floor and stuffed up the door-crack again.
column3: When Jake went out, Marek crawled along the floor and stuffed up the door crack again.

column2: Then, quietly as a shadow, Mr. Shimerda came out from behind the stove.
column3: Then, quietly as a shadow, mr Shimerda came out from behind the stove.

column2: He stood brushing his hand over his smooth gray hair, as if he were trying to clear away a fog about his head.
column3: He stood brushing his hand over his smooth gray hair, as if he were trying to clear away a fog about his head.

column2: He was clean and neat as usual, with his green neckcloth and his coral pin.
column3: He was clean and neat as usual, with his green neckcloth and his coral pin.

column2: He took grandmother's arm and led her behind the stove, to the back of the room. In the rear wall was another little cave; a round hole, not much bigger than an oil barrel, scooped out in the black earth.
column3: He took grandmother's arm and led her behind the stove, to the back of the room. In the rear wall was another little cave; a round hole, not much bigger than an oil barrel, scooped out in the black earth.

column2: When I got up on one of the stools and peered into it, I saw some quilts and a pile of straw. The old man held the lantern.
column3: When I got up on one of the stools and peered into it, I saw some quilts and a pile of straw. The old man held the lantern.

column2: Yulka, he said in a low, despairing voice, "Yulka; my Antonia!"
column3: Yulka, he said in a low, despairing voice, "Yulka; my Antonia!"

column2: Grandmother drew back.
column3: Grandmother drew back.

column2: You mean they sleep in there,--your girls? He bowed his head.
column3: You mean they sleep in there,--your girls? He bowed his head.

column2: Tony slipped under his arm.
column3: Tony slipped under his arm.

column2: It is very cold on the floor, and this is warm like the badger hole.	It is very cold on the floor, and this is warm like the badger hole.

column2: I like for sleep there," she insisted eagerly. "My mamenka have nice bed, with pillows from our own geese in Bohemie. See, Jim?" She pointed to the narrow bunk which Krajiek had built against the wall for himself before the Shimerdas came.
column3: I like for sleep there," she insisted eagerly. "My mamenka have nice bed, with pillows from our own geese in Bohemie. See, Jim?" She pointed to the narrow bunk which Krajiek had built against the wall for himself before the Shimerdas came.

column2: Grandmother sighed.
column3: Grandmother sighed.

column2: Sure enough, where _would_ you sleep, dear!	Sure enough, where underscore would underscore you sleep, dear!

column2: I don't doubt you're warm there.
column3: I don't doubt you're warm there.

column2: You'll have a better house after while, Antonia, and then you'll forget these hard times."
column3: You'll have a better house after while, Antonia, and then you'll forget these hard times."

column2: Mr. Shimerda made grandmother sit down on the only chair and pointed his wife to a stool beside her.
column3: mr Shimerda made grandmother sit down on the only chair and pointed his wife to a stool beside her.

column2: Standing before them with his hand on Antonia's shoulder, he talked in a low tone, and his daughter translated. He wanted us to know that they were not beggars in the old country; he made good wages, and his family were respected there.
column3: Standing before them with his hand on Antonia's shoulder, he talked in a low tone, and his daughter translated. He wanted us to know that they were not beggars in the old country; he made good wages, and his family were respected there.

column2: He left Bohemia with more than a thousand dollars in savings, after their passage money was paid.
column3: He left Bohemia with more than a thousand dollars in savings, after their passage money was paid.

column2: He had in some way lost on exchange in New York, and the railway fare to Nebraska was more than they had expected.
column3: He had in some way lost on exchange in New York, and the railway fare to Nebraska was more than they had expected.

column2: By the time they paid Krajiek for the land, and bought his horses and oxen and some old farm machinery, they had very little money left.
column3: By the time they paid Krajiek for the land, and bought his horses and oxen and some old farm machinery, they had very little money left.

column2: He wished grandmother to know, however, that he still had some money.
column3: He wished grandmother to know, however, that he still had some money.

column2: If they could get through until spring came, they would buy a cow and chickens and plant a garden, and would then do very well.
column3: If they could get through until spring came, they would buy a cow and chickens and plant a garden, and would then do very well.

column2: Ambrosch and Antonia were both old enough to work in the fields, and they were willing to work.
column3: Ambrosch and Antonia were both old enough to work in the fields, and they were willing to work.

column2: But the snow and the bitter weather had disheartened them all.
column3: But the snow and the bitter weather had disheartened them all.

column2: Antonia explained that her father meant to build a new house for them in the spring; he and Ambrosch had already split the logs for it, but the logs were all buried in the snow, along the creek where they had been felled.
column3: Antonia explained that her father meant to build a new house for them in the spring; he and Ambrosch had already split the logs for it, but the logs were all buried in the snow, along the creek where they had been felled.

column2: While grandmother encouraged and gave them advice, I sat down on the floor with Yulka and let her show me her kitten.
column3: While grandmother encouraged and gave them advice, I sat down on the floor with Yulka and let her show me her kitten.

column2: Marek slid cautiously toward us and began to exhibit his webbed fingers.
column3: Marek slid cautiously toward us and began to exhibit his webbed fingers.

column2: I knew he wanted to make his queer noises for me--to bark like a dog or whinny like a horse,--but he did not dare in the presence of his elders.
column3: I knew he wanted to make his queer noises for me-to bark like a dog or whinny like a horse,--but he did not dare in the presence of his elders.

column2: Marek was always trying to be agreeable, poor fellow, as if he had it on his mind that he must make up for his deficiencies.
column3: Marek was always trying to be agreeable, poor fellow, as if he had it on his mind that he must make up for his deficiencies.

column2: Mrs. Shimerda grew more calm and reasonable before our visit was over, and, while Antonia translated, put in a word now and then on her own account.
column3: mrs Shimerda grew more calm and reasonable before our visit was over, and, while Antonia translated, put in a word now and then on her own account.

column2: The woman had a quick ear, and caught up phrases whenever she heard English spoken.
column3: The woman had a quick ear, and caught up phrases whenever she heard English spoken.

column2: As we rose to go, she opened her wooden chest and brought out a bag made of bed-ticking, about as long as a flour sack and half as wide, stuffed full of something.
column3: As we rose to go, she opened her wooden chest and brought out a bag made of bed ticking, about as long as a flour sack and half as wide, stuffed full of something.

column2: At sight of it, the crazy boy began to smack his lips.
column3: At sight of it, the crazy boy began to smack his lips.

column2: When Mrs. Shimerda opened the bag and stirred the contents with her hand, it gave out a salty, earthy smell, very pungent, even among the other odors of that cave.
column3: When mrs Shimerda opened the bag and stirred the contents with her hand, it gave out a salty, earthy smell, very pungent, even among the other odors of that cave.

column2: She measured a teacup full, tied it up in a bit of sacking, and presented it ceremoniously to grandmother.
column3: She measured a teacup full, tied it up in a bit of sacking, and presented it ceremoniously to grandmother.

column2: For cook, she announced.
column3: For cook, she announced.

column3: Little now; be very much when cook, spreading out her hands as if to indicate that the pint would swell to a gallon. "Very good.

column2: You no have in this country.
column3: You no have in this country.

column2: All things for eat better in my country."
column3: All things for eat better in my country."

column2: Maybe so, Mrs. Shimerda, grandmother said drily.
column3: Maybe so, mrs Shimerda, grandmother said drily.

column2: I can't say but I prefer our bread to yours, myself.
column3: I can't say but I prefer our bread to yours, myself.

column3: [Illustration: mrs Shimerda gathering mushrooms in a Bohemian forest]

column2: Antonia undertook to explain.
column3: Antonia undertook to explain.

column2: This very good, Mrs. Burden,--she clasped her hands as if she could not express how good,--"it make very much when you cook, like what my mama say.
column3: This very good, mrs Burden,--she clasped her hands as if she could not express how good,--"it make very much when you cook, like what my mama say.

column2: Cook with rabbit, cook with chicken, in the gravy,--oh, so good!"
column3: Cook with rabbit, cook with chicken, in the gravy,--oh, so good!"

column2: All the way home grandmother and Jake talked about how easily good Christian people could forget they were their brothers' keepers.
column3: All the way home grandmother and Jake talked about how easily good Christian people could forget they were their brothers' keepers.

column2: I will say, Jake, some of our brothers and sisters are hard to keep. Where's a body to begin, with these people?	I will say, Jake, some of our brothers and sisters are hard to keep. Where's a body to begin, with these people?
column3: true

column2: They're wanting in everything, and most of all in horse-sense.
column3: They're wanting in everything, and most of all in horse sense.

column2: Nobody can give 'em that, I guess.
column3: Nobody can give 'em that, I guess.

column2: Jimmy, here, is about as able to take over a homestead as they are.
column3: Jimmy, here, is about as able to take over a homestead as they are.

column2: Do you reckon that boy Ambrosch has any real push in him?"
column3: Do you reckon that boy Ambrosch has any real push in him?"

column2: He's a worker, all right, mam, and he's got some ketch-on about him; but he's a mean one.	He's a worker, all right, mam, and he's got some ketch on about him; but he's a mean one.
column3: true

column2: Folks can be mean enough to get on in this world; and then, ag'in, they can be too mean."
column3: Folks can be mean enough to get on in this world; and then, ag'in, they can be too mean."

column2: That night, while grandmother was getting supper, we opened the package Mrs. Shimerda had given her.
column3: That night, while grandmother was getting supper, we opened the package mrs Shimerda had given her.

column2: It was full of little brown chips that looked like the shavings of some root.
column3: It was full of little brown chips that looked like the shavings of some root.

column2: They were as light as feathers, and the most noticeable thing about them was their penetrating, earthy odor.
column3: They were as light as feathers, and the most noticeable thing about them was their penetrating, earthy odor.

column2: We could not determine whether they were animal or vegetable.
column3: We could not determine whether they were animal or vegetable.

column2: They might be dried meat from some queer beast, Jim.	They might be dried meat from some queer beast, Jim.
column3: true

column2: They ain't dried fish, and they never grew on stalk or vine.
column3: They ain't dried fish, and they never grew on stalk or vine.

column2: I'm afraid of 'em.
column3: I'm afraid of 'em.

column2: Anyhow, I should n't want to eat anything that had been shut up for months with old clothes and goose pillows."
column3: Anyhow, I should n't want to eat anything that had been shut up for months with old clothes and goose pillows."

column2: She threw the package into the stove, but I bit off a corner of one of the chips I held in my hand, and chewed it tentatively.
column3: She threw the package into the stove, but I bit off a corner of one of the chips I held in my hand, and chewed it tentatively.

column2: I never forgot the strange taste; though it was many years before I knew that those little brown shavings, which the Shimerdas had brought so far and treasured so jealously, were dried mushrooms.
column3: I never forgot the strange taste; though it was many years before I knew that those little brown shavings, which the Shimerdas had brought so far and treasured so jealously, were dried mushrooms.
